title: Fitts's Law: Why Big Buttons Work
description: Learn Fitts's Law: Why Big Buttons Work in one minute.

hook.text: The bigger and closer a button is, the faster you can click it. That's not obvious â€” it's math.

buildup.text: Paul Fitts proved in 1954 that movement time depends on distance and target size logarithmically.

discovery.text: Fitts's Law is why OK buttons are large, why docks are at screen edges, and why menus hug corners.

twist.text: Screen corners have infinite size in Fitts's terms â€” you can't overshoot them. That's why the Start menu is there.

climax.text: One equation from 1954 still governs where every button on your phone and computer is placed.

punchline.text: Button placement isn't guesswork. It's physics.

quiz.question: What does Fitts's Law predict?
options: Time to reach a target based on size and distance
